An F test of the percentage of time participants in Experiment 3 agreed to run the filter with condition (positive, negative, or neutral prime) as the independent variable yielded a significant effect of condition. Participants in the neutral condition said they would run the filters 67%of the time, on average. Those in the negative-traits conditions chose to run the filters 73% of the time, but those who wrote about the positive traits were the least cooperative and said they would run the filters only 56% of the time, F(2, 43) = 3.59, p_rep = .90, partial eta squared = 0.143.

Conditional on attempted enforcement, net support for the authority (−3 to +3) was 0.89 in the salary treatment, as compared with −0.21 in the appropriation treatment (p < .001, two-tailed). In other words, on average, about one in three untargeted citizens chose to assist a salaried authority in her enforcement duties. Untargeted citizens intervened less often in the appropriation treatment — and more likely than not on behalf of the target.

for those who expressed goals to increase extraversion, the intervention facilitated growth in trait-extraversion (simple Intervention by Month interaction: b = .06, 95% CI[.02, .11]). Supporting the authors' argument, senators appear to have strategically changed whether they mentioned pro-immigration actions in their explanations depending on the constituents' position. When receiving a pro-immigration letter from a constituent, 23.2% of letters mentioned reinforcing or compensating pro-immigration actions. This was nearly double the 12.5% of letters that mentioned pro-immigration actions in response to anti-immigration letters (p = 0.07 [two-tailed], based on the exact McNemar significance probability).

Following a 2 X 2 X 3 repeated-measures ANOVA with mask–target stimulus onset asynchrony (SOA), prime–target compatibility, and action-effect interval on ratings of control, a post-hoc Fisher test found higher control ratings for compatible prime-targets than incompatible prime-targets in NCE (negative compatibility effect, i.e. long SOA) trials, p = 0.03.

There is a significant and negative interaction term between education level and 4 year college completion on verbal skill utilization for men, coefficient =  -1.648, p < 0.001 (The authors interpret substantive significance using the effect size, see Table 4: comparing cohorts that are 8 percent vs. 40 percent college educated, a hypothetical man with a college degree loses .32 points for verbal skill utilization, and this drop in verbal skill utilization is roughly the difference between a news reporter and a librarian). Thus, although individuals with college experience use verbal skills more than those without a college background do, this advantage declines as the proportion of college-educated individuals increases.

Infants’ ability to predict the goal of manual actions directed toward the mouth (i.e. looking at the mouth area of interest prior to the tool reaching the actor’s mouth) varies dramatically between cultural contexts. Chinese infants fixate the mouth before food arrives there, if chopsticks are used to manipulate the food. If a typically Western-style spoon is used to manipulate the food, however, then Chinese infants fail to predict these events. Swedish infants demonstrate the opposite pattern of results, predicting that food being handled by a Western-style spoon will go to the mouth, but fail to predict the same goal when the action is per-formed with chopsticks.

The authors' main goal is to investigate if the effect of the CFC program on student achievement will be mediated by changes in quality of text discussion. Since they are interested in student level outcomes, the mediator is at the teacher level, and random assignment occurred at the school level, they use a 3 -> 2 -> 1 mediation design (Pituch et al., 2010). To test the indirect effect, they followed the procedure described by Pituch et al. (2010). They constructed confidence intervals using the Sobel (1982) standard error (see p. 41). They used the PRODCLIN software program to test the significance of the indirect effect.

The cross-level interaction between individual and managerial unit–level human capital is negative and significant (gamma21 = −2.66, p < .05, see Figure 2). The pattern of the interaction supported Hypothesis 2, which predicted that the level of managerial unit–level human capital moderates the individual-level human capital and performance relationship such that high levels of managerial unit–level human capital lessen the positive relationship between human capital and performance at the individual level.
